text: As a hiring manager, if I were using these titles, there is a difference. Not in status (one is not higher than the other), but in responsibilities. In my mind, a content manager is solely responsible for creating and managing content. A content marketing manager is also a content creator, but has an added responsibility of how to promote that content. That's how I would perceive it, if I were hiring for those roles. Hope that's helpful.

text: Knowing how to track, define, analyze, and share data is the easiest way to get others to see the value of content as well as get yourself promoted. I have always found it to be a struggle since it’s nowhere close to my areas of expertise and have lacked support from ops roles to help.

text: <@U02UTRR1LFN> - definitely a good point! What are some KPIs you'd like more info on?

elements.text: - definitely a good point! What are some KPIs you'd like more info on?

text: Being able to get realistic/clean data is also a struggle. I find time on page helpful, but it’s so often muddled by other things that it doesn’t provide a clear or accurate picture. Easily understanding which pieces people do read, which CTAs lead to conversions, which distribution tactics work best, clarity on which callouts within articles are getting clicks or leading to conversions… things like that.

text:
Hey <@U035JHVUZ0F> I’d love to help you! I  advise aspiring marketing leaders thru 1:1 coaching currently; (and I’m planning to launch a group cohort program in May). We cover all things marketing and leadership - and the results have been bigger marketing budgets, promotions, higher salaries and credibility and influence at the leadership table.

A quick background on me: 5 x Fortune 500 marketer, B2C and B2B, equal parts strategy and execution role, marketing consultant/ CMO for scale-ups, 2 x marketing author.
(I’m in South Florida - same time zone as you too) :)

text:
Just an idea…but I see a huge gap in b2b content strategy that considers the sales process and involves the sales team.

I work with scaling b2b companies to help guide their marketing strategy which includes everything - customer research, value prop, targeting, content plan and tactical roadmap (including sales enablement).

A differentiating strategy would be to show how you involve the sales team to gain better alignment, extract customer insights from sales, and ensure they will actually use the content created :slightly_smiling_face:
